results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 11]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film is a scenic tour of mostly seaside places, from Sydney Harbour and Port Phillip Bay to a brief look at Phillip Island. The Rankine family members feature and are joined by Bob Wootton late in the reel who contributes to their roadside picnic by cooking meat on a barbecue over a fire in a tin. Kenneth uses individual title cards to clearly point out the locations he is filming and fnishes sunset scenes. Kenneth also uses title cards to introduce each sequence.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:12:00 ‘Sydney and the Harbour’, views across the Harbour to residential areas; Kenneth appears to be filming from a vantage point on the water.

00:01:07:00 Harbour Bridge followed by shots of ferries and dockside buildings; a larger ship comes into view as well as Fort Denison Island and a longer shot of the Harbour Bridge.

00:03:20:00 ‘Manly’, the pier and some buildings.

00:03:40:00 shops and shoppers with the camera taking in the view down to the Harbour; beach scenes and a large ship in the distance.

00:04:48:00 ‘Blue Mountains from Echo Point’ is followed by dramatic views over the mountain ranges and rock formations.

00:05::39:00 the Rankines meeting some other travellers along a walking track.

00:05:51:00 scenes of a sports club and members relaxing, the men are in blazers.

00:06:16:00 ‘The Cascades Leura’, waterfalls, a footbridge and Mrs and Miss Rankine splashing at the foot of a waterfall.

00:07:41:00 a band playing in a large rotunda Spanish exhibition dancing for onlookers; this sequence also shows good examples of vintage bathers.

00:08:32:00 ‘St Kilda’, the St Kilda Botanical Gardens.

00:09:17:00 scenes looking across Pier Rd to the St Kilda Pier, kiosk and a yacht followed by shots of swimmers.

00:10:07:00 ‘At Elwood’ shows more examples of vintage bathing costumes with a beach coat and caps and launching a sail boat straight from the sand.

00:11:14:00 ‘At Mid Brighton’ small craft bobbing in shallow waters followed by a yacht race and Kenneth’s daughter with binoculars looking on.

00:13:07:00 ‘At Sandringham’ shows another sequence of swimmers, people sunbathing, sailboats and diving from what might be an old piece of a jetty, sitting on rocks on the shoreline; there are bathing boxes in the background on the beach.

00:16:50:00 a small boat being hoisted down from a shed and rolled on tracks into the water.

00:18:00:00 onwards we see the Rankines joined by Bob Wootton who contributes to their roadside picnic with his meat patties/ burgers, barbecued over a fire in a tin.

00:18:32:00 ‘Phillip Island’ is introduced with a postcard before coastal views and several shots of koalas in trees, the family wandering along a road.

results.title: DreamWorks Animation Masterclass: Doug Cooper
results.creator_credit: Jesse Taylorsmith, Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description:
At the heart of DreamWorks Animation is the desire to tell great stories and inspire audiences.

In a series of masterclass sessions, the creative team behind the studio that brought us ‘Kung Fu Panda’, ‘Shrek’ and ‘Madagascar’, gave an exclusive look inside the professional animation industry.

Doug Cooper (VFX Supervisor) joined DreamWorks in 1998 as a CG Effects Animator and Technical Director on ‘The Prince of Egypt’ and went on to serve as the Digital Supervisor on ‘Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron’. Previous credits as VFX supervisor include ‘Bee Movie’ and ‘First Flight’ (an animated short).

results.title: DreamWorks: in conversation with Bill Damaschke
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI

video_links.name: DreamWorks: in conversation with Bill Damaschke

results.brief_description:
Go behind the scenes of DreamWorks Animation’s incredible success story with one of the key architects of its amazing 20-year journey - Chief Creative Officer Bill Damaschke.
From overseeing the creative production and development processes for the studio’s feature projects, to shaping the creative teams behind each project and growing the studio’s creative talent pool, Damaschke has played an integral role in bringing the DreamWorks worlds to the big screen.
Damaschke joined DreamWorks in 1995 and served as a producer and executive producer on a number of the studio’s feature films before being named Head of Creative Production in 1999, Head of Creative Production and Development in 2005 and Co-President of Production for Feature Animation and President of Live Theatricals in 2007.
During his tenure at DreamWorks Animation, Damaschke has overseen the release of a range of key DreamWorks titles, from the Academy Award-winning blockbuster ‘Shrek’ in 2001 through to the highly anticipated ‘How to Train Your Dragon 2’.
In Australia to celebrate the opening of the ‘DreamWorks Animation: The Exhibition’, Damaschke joined us for this one off event to discuss his exceptional creative career, his central role in DreamWorks Animation’s future releases, and his insights into the creative hub of one of the world’s most influential animation studios.
Hosted by Walkley Award winning journalist, author, broadcaster and presenter of ABC News Breakfast Virginia Trioli.

results.title: Haircuts and Music: Robert Forster in conversation with Michael Dwyer
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, Shelley Matulick and ACMI

video_links.name: Haircuts and Music: Robert Forster in conversation with Michael Dwyer

results.brief_description: Every change that David Bowie makes comes with a new haircut. The boy can’t help it. As the seventies was his greatest decade as a songwriter and musician, so we marvel at his hair at that time. From Bowie’s first steps into the music business in the mid-sixties, he was a keen student of rock history and the supreme importance of an artist’s image. Each of his hairstyles from that time on alerted the public to where he was musically. Robert Forster will guide us, and plot the Bowie seventies journey from the hippy locks of ‘The Man Who Sold The World’, to the famous Ziggy cut and album, to the coiffured soul-boy of ‘Young Americans’, through to the dramatic renunciation of image that Bowie’s return to his natural hair colour and style for the fabled ‘Berlin Trilogy’ of albums represented.
results.title_for_label: Haircuts and Music: Robert Forster in conversation with Michael Dwyer

results.title: DreamWorks: in conversation with Jeffrey Katzenberg
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI

video_links.name: DreamWorks: in conversation with Jeffrey Katzenberg

results.brief_description:
CEO and co-founder of DreamWorks speaks exclusively about creating, leading and inspiring the world’s largest animation studio in this rare one-off Australian event. A must-see for filmmakers, animators, fans and would-be moguls of tomorrow, hosted by Channel 10’s Executive General Manager, Russel Howcroft (best known as The Gruen Transfer’s advertising media personality).
Katzenberg began his career at Paramount Pictures before moving to Walt Disney Pictures where he is credited with turning the ailing animation studio around. Under his management, Disney produced some of their most critically acclaimed and highest grossing features to date, including ‘The Little Mermaid’ and ‘The Lion King’. He also secured a successful partnership with Pixar Studios and helped bring Miramax Films to Disney. Katzenberg eventually joined forces with Steven Spielberg and David Geffen to start DreamWorks SKG.
Under Katzenberg’s leadership, DreamWorks has become the largest animation studio in the world releasing 28 animated feature films, which have enjoyed both critical and commercial success, earning nine Academy Award nominations, twice winning Best Animated Feature.
In 2013, Katzenberg was awarded the prestigious Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences for his outstanding contributions to humanitarian causes.
Together with his wife Marilyn, Katzenberg provides support and leads fundraising efforts focused predominately on healthcare, education, the arts and the environment.

Proudly supported by the United States Consulate General Melbourne.

results.title: DreamWorks: Inside the Studio
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Venture behind the scenes and uncover the history and creative process behind some of the world’s most popular animated films with this fascinating exploration of the DreamWorks Animation creative studio.

Join special international DreamWorks guests Bill Damaschke (Chief Creative Officer), Kendal Cronkhite (Production Designer), Christophe Lautrette (Production Designer), Jason Schleifer (Head of Character Animation) and Doug Cooper (Visual Effects Supervisor) as they take us inside the DreamWorks phenomenon and explore how the animation and artwork has evolved over the history of the studio’s many hit titles.

Offering key insights into the creative history of the studio and exploring the artwork that has inspired artists and animators all over the world, these talented DreamWorks creatives will also examine the joint curatorial process behind showcasing the art form in the groundbreaking ‘DreamWorks Animation: The Exhibition’ shown at ACMI from 10th April to 5th October 2014.

results.title: [KenRa Films Present: the Kenneth Rankine Home Movie Collection: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
Kenneth Carruthers Rankine (1890 - 1968) was a keen amateur cinematographer and filmmaker. This collection of his home movies has been donated to ACMI by Kenneth’s granddaughter. The collection represents a wonderful slice of life in Australia; with contents including scenes of everyday life, major family occasions, holidays around Victoria and views of Melbourne.

This film, ‘The Sequel’, shows various snapshots of his travels almost as if these scenes are the offcuts of other reels. It is more difficult to locate his footage as Kenneth has not included his usual signs and location titles.

Selected highlights list:

00:00:06:00 title ‘The Sequel’ followed by scenes of waterways, a building with razorwire brick fence, houses, sloping green landscapes and various sea vessels back on the water - ferries, larger and smaller boats and sailing boats all in quick succession.

00:02:08:00 a train carrying coal, then more waterways including a road causeway across the water, a large church and a large hill and more water scenes.

00:02:38:00 prosperous looking farmland, market gardens and houses on a hillside, trees and hills and the sea.

00:03:20:00 old, crumbling buildings on a large scale; a newer house and a woman chopping wood followed by scenes of houses. a town street and farmland near a river and hills.

00:04:30:00 ‘Blue Horizon’ title begins a sequence of houses and a town along a river and the sea, Bettye Rankine and Bob Wootton walking on the sand.

00:05:35:00 the first of a few upside-down frames appear - a church and a town. These are followed by scenes of a large and possibly industrial country town near the sea.

00:07:17:00 shot of a steam train and an engine reversing into a crowded station.

results.title: [Charles Hayes Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
The Charles Hayes Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm and 9.5mm film between the 1940s and 1970s by Charles Edward Hayes (1914–1993).The resulting footage shows us the life of a family living in Heathmont in Melbourne’s south east with their many pets and farm animals, their family holidays and gatherings, their suburb and their cars as well as scenes from Melbourne at the time.

This film shows a little of suburban life in Heathmont when it was first being developed. We see some examples of vintage cars as they were at the time. One of the residents is a young Ron Barassi of Australian Rules Football fame, and Victorian of the Year in 2009, who lived in Heathmont from 1957 to the late 1970s when he moved to St Kilda in Melbourne.

Indoor scenes of the family home show family members with some of their many pets a highlight of which is a game of table tennis with their pet cockatoo and cat.

The film includes a trip to the beach with some some great examples of vintage bathing suits.

Also seen in the film are the Gas and Fuel Corporation buildings on Flinders St which were built in 1967 and demolished in 1997 to make way for the current Federation Square in Melbourne.

Another glimpse of Melbourne’s history flashes across the family television screen - the logo for ‘Channel O’ which was the precursor to the current Channel 10 television station.

There is also a segment showing a small or home based packaging business for what appears to be health food products. The film ends with some travel scenes.

Originally made using Standard 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:01:34:00 Gas & Fuel building on the site of current Federation Square
00:01:49:00 Ron Barassi standing in front of his home
00:08:55:00 Ticka the cockatoo and the family cat play table tennis with the family
00:11:16:00 home based health food business in production at the kitchen table

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Leo Baker
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick, Mike Kenneally, Richard Greenhalgh and ACMI
results.brief_description: Celebrated animator Leo Baker discusses working with Australian band ‘Children Collide’ to create a hybrid live-action and animation video for their song ‘Praying for Sunshine’. Aside from making music videos, Baker was also one of the lead animators on the Oscar-winning screen adaptation of Shaun Tan’s acclaimed ‘The Lost Thing’.

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Natasha Pincus
results.creator_credit: Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick, Mike Kenneally and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Natasha Pincus is a multi award winning Australian music video director and producer and has won the ARIA award for Best Music Video two years in a row. Her stop motion animation video for Gotye’s ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ has had a staggering 420 million views. Natasha talks about getting her first big break making a music video for Paul Kelly.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.
